qas.question: What was given in exchange of signing the document?
What other methods were used to break up protests?
Who did the New York Times report was investigating the school collapses?
What are officials seeking to do about protesting parents?
What are officials offering parents in exchange of protests?
What has happened to some who refuse to agree to not protest?
What did officials order Chinese news media to stop reporting?

context: The New York Times reported that "<a2_0>government officials<a2_0/> in Beijing and Sichuan have said they are investigating the collapses. In an acknowledgment of the weakness of building codes in the countryside, the National Development and Reform Commission said on May 27 that it had drafted an amendment to improve construction standards for primary and middle schools in rural areas. Experts are reviewing the draft, the commission said." To <a3_0>limit protests<a3_0/>, officials pushed parents to sign a document, which forbade them from holding protests, in exchange of <a0_0><a4_0>money<a4_0/><a0_0/>, but some who refused to sign <a5_0>were threatened<a5_0/>. The payment amounts varied from school to school but were approximately the same. In Hanwang, parents were offered a package valued at 8,800 USD in cash and a per-parent pension of nearly 5,600 USD. Furthermore, officials used other methods of silencing: <a1_0>riot police<a1_0/> officers broke up protests by parents; the authorities set up cordons around the schools; and officials ordered the Chinese news media to stop reporting <a6_0>on school collapses<a6_0/>.
